head.title: How Mr. Fish Helped Preserve Hudson Valley

hedline.hl1: How Mr. Fish Helped Preserve Hudson Valley

block.p: Is 18 1/2 years too long to fulfill a prophecy? Not when it results in nuclear freedom for the Mid-Hudson Valley in New York State.
Is 18 1/2 years too long to fulfill a prophecy? Not when it results in nuclear freedom for the Mid-Hudson Valley in New York State.

In November 1976 the Consolidated Edison Company of New York announced its intention to build what was reputed to be one of the world's largest nuclear or coal-fired power plants, 5,200 megawatts, in the midst of one of the most beautiful scenic areas on this continent, the Mid-Hudson Valley.

In April 1978 Representative Hamilton Fish joined our group, Mid-Hudson Nuclear Opponents, in a lawsuit to prevent the siting of this plant. We lost the suit. Although the construction of the plant had been publicly announced, the court said it could not rule on an academic question, or a speculative issue that might arise some time in the future. Representative Fish reassured us with a sage comment: "Time and technology are on your side."

In May 1994 Consolidated Edison concluded that the plant was unnecessary and would not be constructed. In the intervening 18 1/2 years only 62 percent of the land projected for acquisition had been purchased, much of it at well above prevailing market value.

The local towns of Red Hook, Milan and Clermont have on their 1995 agenda the disposition of the properties involved. Wouldn't it be a wonderful tribute to Representative Fish, now retired, if these towns agreed to create a contiguous trail for the public's use, and named it after him? AILEEN M. KOROB Red Hook, N.Y., Jan. 23, 1995
